trans-unit.source: Managing databases and logins in Azure SQL Database | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Managing databases and logins in Azure SQL Database | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How you can use the server-level principal and other accounts to manage logins and databases in SQL Database
trans-unit.target: How you can use the server-level principal and other accounts to manage logins and databases in SQL Database

trans-unit.source: In Microsoft Azure SQL Database, when you sign up for the service, the provisioning process creates an Azure SQL Database server, a database named master, and a login that is the server-level principal of your Azure SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: In Microsoft Azure SQL Database, when you sign up for the service, the provisioning process creates an Azure SQL Database server, a database named master, and a login that is the server-level principal of your Azure SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: That login is similar to the server-level principal, sa, for an instance of SQL Server on your premises.
trans-unit.target: That login is similar to the server-level principal, sa, for an instance of SQL Server on your premises.

trans-unit.source: The Azure SQL Database server-level principal account always has permission to manage all server-level and database-level security.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SQL Database server-level principal account always has permission to manage all server-level and database-level security.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how you can use the server-level principal and other accounts to manage logins and databases in SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how you can use the server-level principal and other accounts to manage logins and databases in SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: SQL Database V12 allows users to authenticate at the database by using contained database users.
trans-unit.target: SQL Database V12 allows users to authenticate at the database by using contained database users.

trans-unit.source: Contained database users do not require logins.
trans-unit.target: Contained database users do not require logins.

trans-unit.source: This makes databases more portable but reduces the ability of the server-level principal to control access to the database.
trans-unit.target: This makes databases more portable but reduces the ability of the server-level principal to control access to the database.

trans-unit.source: Enabling contained database users has important security impacts.
trans-unit.target: Enabling contained database users has important security impacts.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Contained Database Users - Making Your Database Portable</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Contained Databases</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Contained Database Users - Making Your Database Portable</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Contained Databases</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Security administration in SQL Database is similar to security administration for an on-premises instance of SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Security administration in SQL Database is similar to security administration for an on-premises instance of SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Managing security at the database-level is almost identical, with differences only in the parameters available.
trans-unit.target: Managing security at the database-level is almost identical, with differences only in the parameters available.

trans-unit.source: Because SQL Databases can scale to one or more physical computers, Azure SQL Database uses a different strategy for server-level administration.
trans-unit.target: Because SQL Databases can scale to one or more physical computers, Azure SQL Database uses a different strategy for server-level administration.

trans-unit.source: The following table summarizes how security administration for an on-premise SQL Server is different than in Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The following table summarizes how security administration for an on-premise SQL Server is different than in Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Point of Difference
trans-unit.target: Point of Difference

trans-unit.source: On-premises SQL Server
trans-unit.target: On-premises SQL Server

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.target: Where you manage server-level security

trans-unit.target: The Security folder in SQL Server Management Studio's Object Explorer

trans-unit.source: The master database and through the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: The master database and through the Azure portal

trans-unit.target: Server-level security role for creating logins

trans-unit.source: securityadmin fixed server role For more information, see Server-Level Roles
trans-unit.target: securityadmin fixed server role For more information, see Server-Level Roles

trans-unit.source: loginmanager database role in the master
trans-unit.target: loginmanager database role in the master

trans-unit.target: Commands for managing logins

trans-unit.target: CREATE LOGIN, ALTER LOGIN, DROP LOGIN (There are some parameter limitations and you must be connected to the master database)

trans-unit.target: View that shows all logins

trans-unit.target: sys.sql_logins (You must be connected to the master database)

trans-unit.target: Server-level role for creating databases

trans-unit.target: dbcreator fixed database role For more information, see Server-Level Roles

trans-unit.target: dbmanager database role in the master database

trans-unit.target: Command for creating a database

trans-unit.target: CREATE DATABASE

trans-unit.target: CREATE DATABASE (There are some parameter limitations and you must be connected to the master database)

trans-unit.target: View that lists all databases

trans-unit.target: sys.databases

trans-unit.source: sys.databases (You must be connected to the master database)
trans-unit.target: sys.databases (You must be connected to the master database)

trans-unit.source: Your Azure SQL Database server is an abstraction that defines a grouping of databases.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure SQL Database server is an abstraction that defines a grouping of databases.

trans-unit.source: Databases associated with your Azure SQL Database server may reside on separate physical computers at the Microsoft data center.
trans-unit.target: Databases associated with your Azure SQL Database server may reside on separate physical computers at the Microsoft data center.

trans-unit.source: Perform server-level administration for all of them by using a single database named master.
trans-unit.target: Perform server-level administration for all of them by using a single database named master.

trans-unit.source: The master database keeps track of logins, and which logins have permission to create databases or other logins.
trans-unit.target: The master database keeps track of logins, and which logins have permission to create databases or other logins.

trans-unit.source: You must be connected to the master database whenever you create, alter, or drop logins or databases.
trans-unit.target: You must be connected to the master database whenever you create, alter, or drop logins or databases.

trans-unit.source: The master database also has the sys.sql_logins and sys.databases views that you can use to view logins and databases, respectively.
trans-unit.target: The master database also has the sys.sql_logins and sys.databases views that you can use to view logins and databases, respectively.

trans-unit.source: The USE command is not supported for switching between databases.
trans-unit.target: The USE command is not supported for switching between databases.

trans-unit.source: Establish a connection directly to the target database.
trans-unit.target: Establish a connection directly to the target database.

trans-unit.source: You can manage database-level security for users and objects in Microsoft Azure SQL Database the same way you do for an on-premises instance of SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: You can manage database-level security for users and objects in Microsoft Azure SQL Database the same way you do for an on-premises instance of SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: There are differences only in the parameters available to the corresponding commands.
trans-unit.target: There are differences only in the parameters available to the corresponding commands.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure SQL Database security guidelines and limitations</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure SQL Database security guidelines and limitations</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Manage logins with the server-level principal login by connecting to the master database.
trans-unit.target: Manage logins with the server-level principal login by connecting to the master database.

trans-unit.source: You can use the CREATE LOGIN, ALTER LOGIN, or DROP LOGIN statements.
trans-unit.target: You can use the CREATE LOGIN, ALTER LOGIN, or DROP LOGIN statements.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a login named login1:
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a login named login1:

trans-unit.source: You must use a strong password when creating a login.
trans-unit.target: You must use a strong password when creating a login.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In order to connect to Microsoft Azure SQL Database using the logins you create, you must first grant each login database-level permissions by using the CREATE USER command.
trans-unit.target: In order to connect to Microsoft Azure SQL Database using the logins you create, you must first grant each login database-level permissions by using the CREATE USER command.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Granting Database-Level Permissions to a Login.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Granting Database-Level Permissions to a Login.

trans-unit.source: Because some tools implement tabular data stream (TDS) differently, you may need to append the Azure SQL Database server name to the login in the connection string using the @ notation. In these cases, separate the login and Azure SQL Database server name with the @ symbol. For example, if your login was named login1 and the fully qualified name of your Azure SQL Database server is servername.database.windows.net, the username parameter of your connection string should be: login1@servername. This restriction places limitations on the text you can choose for the login name. For more information, see CREATE LOGIN (Transact-SQL).
trans-unit.target: Because some tools implement tabular data stream (TDS) differently, you may need to append the Azure SQL Database server name to the login in the connection string using the @ notation. In these cases, separate the login and Azure SQL Database server name with the @ symbol. For example, if your login was named login1 and the fully qualified name of your Azure SQL Database server is servername.database.windows.net, the username parameter of your connection string should be: login1@servername. This restriction places limitations on the text you can choose for the login name. For more information, see CREATE LOGIN (Transact-SQL).

trans-unit.source: In order for logins other than the server-level principal to manage server-level security, Microsoft Azure SQL Database offers two security roles: loginmanager, for creating logins and dbmanager for creating databases.
trans-unit.target: In order for logins other than the server-level principal to manage server-level security, Microsoft Azure SQL Database offers two security roles: loginmanager, for creating logins and dbmanager for creating databases.

trans-unit.source: Only users in the master database can be added to these database roles.
trans-unit.target: Only users in the master database can be added to these database roles.

trans-unit.source: To create logins or databases, you must be connected to the master database (which is a logical representation of master).
trans-unit.target: To create logins or databases, you must be connected to the master database (which is a logical representation of master).

trans-unit.source: Like the securityadmin fixed server role for an on-premises instance of SQL Server, the loginmanager database role in Microsoft Azure SQL Database is has permission to create logins.
trans-unit.target: Like the securityadmin fixed server role for an on-premises instance of SQL Server, the loginmanager database role in Microsoft Azure SQL Database is has permission to create logins.

trans-unit.source: Only the server-level principal login (created by the provisioning process) or members of the loginmanager database role can create new logins.
trans-unit.target: Only the server-level principal login (created by the provisioning process) or members of the loginmanager database role can create new logins.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Azure SQL Database dbmanager database role is similar to the dbcreator fixed server role for an on-premises instance of SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Azure SQL Database dbmanager database role is similar to the dbcreator fixed server role for an on-premises instance of SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Only the server-level principal login (created by the provisioning process) or members of the dbmanager database role can create databases.
trans-unit.target: Only the server-level principal login (created by the provisioning process) or members of the dbmanager database role can create databases.

trans-unit.source: Once a user is a member of the dbmanager database role, it can create a database with the Azure SQL Database CREATE DATABASE command, but that command must be executed in the master database.
trans-unit.target: Once a user is a member of the dbmanager database role, it can create a database with the Azure SQL Database CREATE DATABASE command, but that command must be executed in the master database.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE DATABASE (SQL Server Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE DATABASE (SQL Server Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To create a login and associated user that can create databases or other logins, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To create a login and associated user that can create databases or other logins, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Connect to the master database using the credentials of the server-level principal login (created by the provisioning process) or the credentials of an existing member of the loginmanager database role.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the master database using the credentials of the server-level principal login (created by the provisioning process) or the credentials of an existing member of the loginmanager database role.

trans-unit.source: Create a login using the CREATE LOGIN command.
trans-unit.target: Create a login using the CREATE LOGIN command.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE LOGIN (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE LOGIN (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Create a new user for that login in the master database using the CREATE USER command.
trans-unit.target: Create a new user for that login in the master database using the CREATE USER command.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use the stored procedure sp_addrolememeber to add new user to the dbmanager database role, the loginmanager database role, or both.
trans-unit.target: Use the stored procedure sp_addrolememeber to add new user to the dbmanager database role, the loginmanager database role, or both.

trans-unit.source: The following code example shows how to create a login named login1, and a corresponding database user named login1User that is able to create databases or other logins while connected to the master database:
trans-unit.target: The following code example shows how to create a login named login1, and a corresponding database user named login1User that is able to create databases or other logins while connected to the master database:

trans-unit.source: You must use a strong password when creating a login.
trans-unit.target: You must use a strong password when creating a login.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: All logins must be created in the master database.
trans-unit.target: All logins must be created in the master database.

trans-unit.source: After a login has been created, you can create a user account in another database for that login.
trans-unit.target: After a login has been created, you can create a user account in another database for that login.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure SQL Database also supports database roles in the same way that an on-premises instance of SQL Server does.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure SQL Database also supports database roles in the same way that an on-premises instance of SQL Server does.

trans-unit.source: To create a user account in another database, assuming you have not created a login or a database, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To create a user account in another database, assuming you have not created a login or a database, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Connect to the master database (with a login having the loginmanager and dbmanager roles).
trans-unit.target: Connect to the master database (with a login having the loginmanager and dbmanager roles).

trans-unit.source: Create a new login using the CREATE LOGIN command.
trans-unit.target: Create a new login using the CREATE LOGIN command.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE LOGIN (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE LOGIN (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Windows Authentication is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Windows Authentication is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Create a new database using the CREATE DATABASE command.
trans-unit.target: Create a new database using the CREATE DATABASE command.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE DATABASE (SQL Server Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE DATABASE (SQL Server Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Establish a connection to the new database (with the login that created the database).
trans-unit.target: Establish a connection to the new database (with the login that created the database).

trans-unit.source: Create a new user on the new database using the CREATE USER command.
trans-unit.target: Create a new user on the new database using the CREATE USER command.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following code example shows how to create a login named login1 and a database named database1:
trans-unit.target: The following code example shows how to create a login named login1 and a database named database1:

trans-unit.source: You must use a strong password when creating a login.
trans-unit.target: You must use a strong password when creating a login.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This next example shows how to create a database user named login1User in the database database1 that corresponds to the login login1:
trans-unit.target: This next example shows how to create a database user named login1User in the database database1 that corresponds to the login login1:

trans-unit.source: This database-level permission model in Microsoft Azure SQL Database is same as an on-premise instance of SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: This database-level permission model in Microsoft Azure SQL Database is same as an on-premise instance of SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: For information, see the following topics in SQL Server Books Online references.
trans-unit.target: For information, see the following topics in SQL Server Books Online references.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Managing Logins, Users, and Schemas How-to Topics</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Managing Logins, Users, and Schemas How-to Topics</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Lesson 2: Configuring Permissions on Database Objects</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Lesson 2: Configuring Permissions on Database Objects</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Security-related Transact-SQL statements in Microsoft Azure SQL Database may differ slightly in the parameters that are available.
trans-unit.target: Security-related Transact-SQL statements in Microsoft Azure SQL Database may differ slightly in the parameters that are available.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure SQL Database Transact-SQL Reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure SQL Database Transact-SQL Reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To view logins and databases on your Azure SQL Database server, use the master database's sys.sql_logins and sys.databases views, respectively.
trans-unit.target: To view logins and databases on your Azure SQL Database server, use the master database's sys.sql_logins and sys.databases views, respectively.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to display a list of all the logins and databases on your Azure SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to display a list of all the logins and databases on your Azure SQL Database server.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SQL Database security guidelines and limitations</linkText><title></title>
